bibl.title: Letter from Delia A. Lynch to Dan B. Butler, April, 13, 1942

div1.p: Lynch requests that Butler meet with Hench to discuss Pinto's recognition for his service in the yellow fever experiments. Lynch adds a note to Hench stating that Butler wishes to meet with him.

div1.head: Letter from Delia A. Lynch to Dan B. Butler, April, 13, 1942
div1.p:
DR. DELIA A. LYNCH
712 WORLD-HERALD BUILDING
PHONE JACKSON 5137
OMAHA
April, 13, 1942 Dear Mayor Butler:

Several years ago the Douglas County Medical Society
and Dr. A. S. Pinto's many friends, started an investigation
to see why he had not received recognition for his merit-
orious service in the yellow fever experiment in 1900.
We were not successful in securing it. The committee stat-
ed he was not in the employ of the government and had not
died from the mosquito bite; in their opinion he was not
entitled to this recognition. The committee in charge were
not physicians but probably politicians consequently their
opinions had no weight in scientific application to such
service. His case, however, was a very deciding link in
the chain of evidence which really did bring about absolute
and accurate conclusion as to the cause of yellow fever.

I am enclosing his picture and copy of war records
also Mayo proceedings which carried history and splendid
pictures of those participating. We think Dr. Pinto should
be included in it. At a recent visit to the Mayo Clinic,
I so expressed myself to Dr. P. S. Hench, who had charge of
this fine history and who is expected in Omaha the last week
of April. Could I plan to ask you to meet him if he so
wishes and can spare the time. He also plans to see Dr. Pinto
while here.

Thanking you for expression of this very important
subject of Dr. A. S. Pinto's recognition.

Our Mayor, Mr. Dan B. Butler, expresses desire to meet
you while here and am enclosing this letter to him. I am
hoping you may be able to stay a few hours. The Mayor fully
appreciates this for Doctor Pinto has been to this community,
similar to what your splindid Mayo Clinic has been to
physicians from all over the country these many years.

Very Sincerely
Dr. Delia A. Lynch
4-17, 1942.
